title: Use long-lived TCP connections.
label: [Label(name="bug")]
body:
Right now, Android puts the network to sleep for intervals which appear to be greater than the ping timeout of the network connection, and Revolution IRC doesn't override this for PING responses.

Theoretically, the messages would sit in the server send-que (tcp level packet que) until they were received by the client (the network is brought back from sleep). However, either the client would need to blindly send PONGs at constant intervals to try and keep the connection alive, or would need to override the battery-saving network sleep and receive packets (even if at set intervals relating to the ping timeout).

title: Warn about addressing an absent nick
label: [Label(name="enhancement")]
body:
One of the problems of using an IRC from a phone or tablet is that typing is slow, so one is much more likely (compared with IRC from traditional devices) to encounter the situation where you're writing something to another user in a channel, and they leave or quit before you hit send.

Ideally, as soon as a nick is fully mentioned at the start of a message (with nick+colon), a check would be done to whether the user is currently in the channel, and as the message is being typed this check would be repeated periodically.

If at any time while typing, the other nick leaves or quits, give a strong visual warning; I suggest turning the text entry area red, if that's not too hard to implement.

Then the user could immediate stop wasting effort typing a message that the intended recipient will never see.

If the same behaviour could be done in PM sessions, that would be a bonus, but I suspect it would be much more difficult without "leave" or "quit" notifications from the server.

title: [REQUEST] Connecting to TLS-encrypted networks
label: [Label(name="enhancement")]
body:
one of the servers I frequent with the box I usually keep irssi connected on requires TLS as the encryption standard for various reasons since the owner of the server is pretty tinfoil-hatted about such things. 

Specifically, the server uses **TLSv1.2-ECDHE-RSA-AES256-GCM-SHA384-256bits** encryption, so says the server status page. 

I don't really see any other IRC clients for Android supporting this-- it might be a good selling point of your client over others to allow for it, since SSL has had problems in the past and everyone will start moving towards this in the future of things as time goes on.

title: Don't send notifications on NOTICEs
label: [Label(name="default behaviour")]
body:
[The IRC RFC says:](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc1459#section-4.4.2)

```
4.4.2 Notice

      Command: NOTICE
   Parameters: <nickname> <text>

   The NOTICE message is used similarly to PRIVMSG.  The difference
   between NOTICE and PRIVMSG is that automatic replies must never be
   sent in response to a NOTICE message.  This rule applies to servers
   too - they must not send any error reply back to the client on
   receipt of a notice.  The object of this rule is to avoid loops
   between a client automatically sending something in response to
   something it received.  This is typically used by automatons (clients
   with either an AI or other interactive program controlling their
   actions) which are always seen to be replying lest they end up in a
   loop with another automaton.

   See PRIVMSG for more details on replies and examples.
```

and I see this generally interpreted that NOTICE is a less important message than PRIVMSG while Revolution IRC appears to send a notification and also vibrates and plays the notification sound.

In spirit of the RFC, my bot is sending all messages as notices except messages it relays from other networks and [Matrix](https://matrix.org) has copied this behaviour and their [IRC bridge](https://github.com/matrix-org/matrix-appservice-irc) causes all bot messages to appear as NOTICEs at IRC.

I think the easiest way to reproduce this on freenode is possibly to invite either `mijris[m]` or `ivar[m]` (Matrix bots) into any channel and saying `!ping` where they reply by saying `pong! <ISO8601 date>`. They accept all invites. (They also shouldn't rejoin after kicked.)

title: Target Android O
label: [Label(name="enhancement"), Label(name="low priority")]
body:
I'd really love to target Android O instead of N but the new notification channel system introduced in O has a fundamental flaw that makes it harder for this application to adapt it.
After creating a notification channel you can't change it in an way. To make things even worse, the channel is stored on the device forever and even if you delete and recreate it, it's settings will be restored. The recommended (and in fact, the only) way to change settings is to direct the user to the Settings app and let user manage the channel options there. But, you can't change the LED color or vibration pattern settings in that menu. The new Settings interface is way more annoying for the user, as currently the options are easily accessible under the notification options in the app and this would require adding an ugly link to go to settings to change those.

Solutions I can think of:
1. Wait for the next Android release, hope that it becomes more advanced (why do I doubt that...) and then make some sort of a broken Android O support workaround while properly supporting the next release.
2. Create a new unique notification channel every time the settings are changed. Con: we waste a small amount of storage each time.
3. Use the NotificationListenerService to edit the channels. Con: requires to be enabled manually by the user in settings, and can be suspicious as it gives the app full notification access.
